history.content: It would be very useful if you are interested in control theory, a critical field in robotics  (120 is required really for control, unless you learn on your own, since the laplace domain, root locus method, etc all are based on 120).  It also covers the background needed for digital signal processing (sampling, filtering etc).  And while most of 120 is background/theory, when I took it last semester, we did have one lab where we learned how to control a lunar rover (how to compensate for the signal delay to the moon).  Personally I'd recommend 120, and if you find control cool, then EE/ME C128.  And for "real world applications," systems and signals are everywhere, applications I can think of in addition to control: MRI, optical engineering, video/image processing (anything to do with DSP), communications, etc.
I'm planning on doing robotics and AI in my career. I'm not sure I'd enjoy 120 if it's about stuff that doesn't really pertain to that. What are the real world applications of EE120 material?
history.subject: How useful actually is EE120
